Issues.Title: feat(bazel): @angular/bazel compat with bazel 0.27 and rules_nodejs 0.32.2
Issues.Body:
Replaces #31019 which was merged but created a g3 issue so was rolled back. This PR includes a minor change to line https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/packages/bazel/src/ng_module.bzl#L272 which should resolve the g3 issue:

```
ERROR: /third_party/javascript/angular2/BUILD:150:1: output 'third_party/javascript/angular2/core_ngc_messages.xmb' was not created
ERROR: /third_party/javascript/angular2/BUILD:150:1: not all outputs were created or valid
Target //javascript/angular2/tools/ngc/e2e:message_extraction_test failed to build
```

* Updates to Bazel 0.27.0 and makes compatibility fixes.
* Updates to rules_nodejs 0.32.2 and makes compatibility fixes for breaking changes since 0.31.x
* Turns on symlinked node_modules finally as 0.32.2 fixes rules_nodejs#802
* Fixes worker mode issue with ts_library (yeay) -- ts_library workers should be turned back on
* Improves how ts_library consumes @types npm packages
***See 0.32.2 release notes for more info: https://github.com/bazelbuild/rules_nodejs/releases/tag/0.32.2***

## rules_nodejs 0.32.0 compat fixes

@npm//node_modules/foobar:foobar.js labels changed to @npm//:node_modules/foobar/foobar.js with fix for bazelbuild/rules_nodejs#802

## Bazel 0.27.0 compat fixes

ctx.new_file is deprecated and ctx.actions.declare_file should be used in Bazel 0.27.0. Error seen here is:
```
        File "ng_module.bzl", line 272, in _expected_outs
                ctx.new_file(ctx.genfiles_dir, (ctx.label.name ..."))
Use ctx.actions.declare_file instead of ctx.new_file.
Use --incompatible_new_actions_api=false to temporarily disable this check.
```
This can be worked around with incompatible_new_actions_api flag but may as well fix it proper so downstream doesn't require this flag due to this code.

Also, depset() is no longer iterable by default without a flag. This required fixing in a few spots in @angular/bazel.

- [x] The commit message follows our guidelines: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#commit

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): handle ICU expressions in `executeActionOnNode`
Issues.Body:
When `walkTNodeTree` was refactored, the case of ICU expressions was forgotten (because it was handled in the `else` previously).
This PR fixes that to handle it like `ElementContainer`.

Issues.Title: refactor(ivy): make style application happen automatically
Issues.Body:
This patch removes the need to issue a call to `stylingApply()`
at the end of change detection within a template or host bindings
function. What will happen instead is when the element is exited
(i.e. when `select(n)` is called, when a template exits or when
all host bindings for an element are processed) then styling will
be flushed automatically.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "refactor(ivy): make style application happen automatically" (#31321)

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): attach host element for views created via TestBed.createComponent
Issues.Body:
Prior to this commit, host element of a view created via TestBed.createComponent was not attached to the component's host, making it problematic to use TestBed.createComponent API in component factories (which might be used for testing purposes - this behavior is observed in google3 app tests). This scenario was supported by VE and this commit aligns Ivy and VE.

This PR resolves FW-1412.

Issues.Title: Different approaches to service injection don't play well together
Issues.Body:
## Summary ##
Since Angular 6 there have been 2 fundamentally different ways of configuring services for injection but these 2 approaches don't interact well with one another which can result in confusing application bugs, and I don't think the implications of the 2 different approaches have been made sufficiently clear in the documentation.

## Caveat ##
I'm not really sure of the best way to categorise this issue. I think documentation improvements could help users to handle this better, but it really seems to me to be more of a design flaw in the service injection framework. From a coding perspective, I'm not really sure what could be done to improve it, but there may well be a good solution that I've been unable to think of.

Much of this problem has already been touched on by a couple of other github issues:
- https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/10170
- https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/25784

## The Current Situation ##
Prior to Angular 6, services were generally configured for injection by decorating the service's containing NgModule as follows:
```
@NgModule({
    providers: [MyService]
})
export class MyServiceModule {
```
But since Angular 6, users have been encouraged to configure services as follows instead:
```
@Injectable({
    providedIn: 'root'
})
export class MyService {
```

The new approach has 2 advantages, namely:
1.  It enables tree-shaking of unused services - since they no longer have to be included in the `providers` array of an NgModule.
2.  It ensures that only one instance of the service will ever exist - _even if the service is consumed by multiple, lazy-loaded modules_

I think it's worth noting however, that:
1.  Tree-shaking of services is only really necessary when writing a third party library. When writing an _application_ it is pretty unlikely that you would include - except perhaps by accident - a service which you weren't intending to use somewhere.
2.  Service duplication can be avoided anyway by taking appropriate care when lazy-loading modules - although the new approach _is_ safer in this respect.

The new approach also has one very important implication though, which I don't think is made sufficiently clear in the documentation, and which in turn can lead to confusing dependency issues when both approaches are used within the same application (or across different libraries which are consumed by that application):

## Service "Ownership" ##
If `MyService` is configured for injection using the `@NgModule` `providers` decoration, the service can rightly be considered to "belong" to that NgModule. It is also therefore that module's responsibility to make sure that it imports any other NgModules which provide services that `MyService` depends on.

If `MyService` is configured using the `@Injectable`, `providedIn: 'root'` syntax though, the service no longer really "belongs" anywhere. It might be co-located with a particular NgModule on the file system, but it has no relationship to it - it doesn't know about the module, and the module doesn't know about the service. This may not be immediately obvious to developers.

Because there is no longer an "owning" NgModule, the `MyService` class will now just be bundled with whatever consumes it, and it is then the _consumer's_ responsibility to ensure that the service's dependencies - i.e. any services which are injected into it - are available. This is fine if all _those_ services have also been configured with `providedIn: 'root'` (and also all of _their_ dependencies, etc.). It becomes more complicated though, in a scenario where interdependencies exist between services that have been configured in different ways - as can easily happen when using third party libraries, or even when consuming built-in Angular services that have been configured via the old-style `providers` array.

## Problem Example ###
Consider the following scenario:

1.  `MyComponent` is in `MyComponentModule` and consumes `MyService` which has been decorated with `providedIn: 'root'`. `MyService` is "in" (but not really - it is just co-located with) `MyServiceModule`.
2.  `MyService` consumes `ThirdPartyService` _which hasn't been similarly decorated_. Instead, `ThirdPartyService` has been provided via the `providers` array in `ThirdPartyServiceModule`.
3. `MyServiceModule` imports `ThirdPartyServiceModule`, but as it turns out this is incidental, because _`MyService` doesn't really belong to `MyServiceModule`_

The code fails at run time, when it attempts to instantiate `MyService` for injection into `MyComponent` with:
```
NullInjectorError: No provider for ThirdPartyService!
```

This is because `MyComponentModule` has not imported `ThirdPartyServiceModule`, but this is not very obvious to the developer. It doesn't seem very logical (to me anyway) that `MyComponentModule` should have to care about `MyService`'s dependencies (or perhaps even its dependencies' dependencies), just because of the different ways in which these services have been configured.

As I say, I don't really know what the best way is to fix this - apart from perhaps making the implications of all this a little clearer in the documentation. The cat is now somewhat out of the bag regarding the (now not-so-)new `providedIn: 'root'` syntax and at the moment I can't think of a way to make these 2 different approaches play nicely with each other.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Different approaches to service injection don't play well together" (#31309)

Issues.Title: Add support for indexing templates
Issues.Body:
@alxhub and I recently discussed how best to implement indexing templates in the [`Ngtsc` indexing module](./packages/compiler-cli/src/ngtsc/indexer). I'm dumping the key points of that discussion here for future reference and discussion.

# üöÄ feature request

### Relevant Package

For @angular/compiler-cli, `Ngtsc` indexer module.

### Description

The compiler's indexing module does not currently support indexing HTML elements in templates. We want to add support for that. Initially, the scope of this was

- Record element selectors used in the template
- Record used directives in the template

such that an indexer could link an element selector to the directive it references, if any. This approach is quite limiting, however, because directive selectors can match on many things beside element selectors, including matching on attributes and implicitly matching on the absence of an attribute. A better approach is

- Record element selectors used in the template
  - each selector record also includes a record of attributes on the element
  - each selector record also includes a record of used directives on the element

To consider the usefulness of this, consider a template like `<my-comp applied-dir>` that uses the directives `MyComp`, `AppliedDir`, and an implicitly loaded directive `ImplicitDir`. The compiler's indexer module will index the template and record an element identifier that looks something like

```typescript
{
  name: 'my-comp',
  span: ...,
  attributes: [ { name: 'applied-dir', span: ... } ],
  usedDirectives: [ MyComp, AppliedDir, ImplicitDir ],
}
```

A source code indexer implementation can then use this information to generate useful references, like xreferencing `my-comp` to the `MyComp` class declaration, `applied-dir` to the `AppliedDir` class declaration, and adding an implicit reference of all three used directives on `my-comp`.

### Alternatives

- Do not record attributes separately; pass the entire element tag source code as the element identifier name instead.
  - __advantages__: less work for the compiler's indexing module.
  - __disadvantages__: an indexer implementation now has to write an HTML parser to discern attributes on the element.
- Perform the linking of attributes to the directives that match it in the compiler.
  - __advantages__: less work for an indexer implementation
  - __disadvantages__: directives are applied to an element, not an attribute, so such an implementation would be needlessly complicated. Furthermore, it is not necessarily the job of the compiler's semantic analysis API to make decisions about what spans of text reference one another, especially in ambiguous cases like the one presented here - that should be on the indexer implementation.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Add support for indexing templates" (#31299)

Issues.Title: bug(build-angular): lack of `Symbol.iterator` support in es5-polyfills
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) ``` - [ ] new - [x] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ``` ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: v7.x Until v7.x, build-angular uses core-js v2. This regression is caused by a breaking change of core-js v3. ### Description A clear and concise description of the problem... **Since v8.0, ES5 polyfills generated by Angular CLI doesn't have `Symbol.iterator` support.** Angular depends on `Symbol.iterator` in such as `HttpHeader` of `@angular/common/http`. https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/packages/common/http/src/headers.ts#L255-L256 ``` Array.from(this.normalizedNames.keys()) ``` `Array.from(iterable)` is ES2015 feature which works with `Array.from` and `Symbol.iterator`. And legacy browsers like IE11 don't have it. So, its polyfill is necessary. CLI v7 used core-js v2 and its `core-js/es6/symbol` contains `Symbol.iterator` support. https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/7.3.x/packages/angular_devkit/build_angular/src/angular-cli-files/models/es2015-polyfills.js Since core-js v3, `Symbol.iterator` has been seperated from `Symbol` itself. - https://github.com/zloirock/core-js/blob/v3.1.4/packages/core-js/modules/es.symbol.js - https://github.com/zloirock/core-js/blob/v3.1.4/packages/core-js/modules/es.symbol.iterator.js Because of that, to support IE11 Angular CLI should include `es.symbol.iterator.js` in `es5-polyfills`. But now CLI lacks it. https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/master/packages/angular_devkit/build_angular/src/angular-cli-files/models/es5-polyfills.js#L10 ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction ## üî• Exception or Error
No errors but `HttpClient.get(..., { headers })` doesn't send headers to server. ## üåç Your Environment
**Anything else relevant?**

Issues.Title: Accessing root address will not redirect to base href
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: 7.2.15 ### Description When you create minimal application, set the base href (e.g. "/test/") and access http://localhost:4200 instead of http://localhost:4200/test/. You are not redirected to http://localhost:4200/test/ but shown white page containing: 
Cannot GET /
In Angular 7, setting the base href will redirect you to http://localhost:4200/test/ when you access http://localhost:4200. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction You can reproduce the problem by creating a minimal Angular application with the CLI. 
ng new angular-basehref-test --interactive=false
cd angular-basehref-test
ng serve --baseHref=/test/

Issues.Title: Invalidating lazy loaded modules
Issues.Body:
Hi!

Hopefully this is the correct repo to ask as I'm not sure if its more related to CLI or angular itself, just as I'm not sure if its intentional or possible bug/feature request, but here we go - I have following setup:

- Differential loading
- Lazy modules
- Angular source files hosted on CDN
- Angular app available on multiple domains

The problem I'm struggling with is that Angular requests all child modules with:

```javascript
https://cdn.net/app/30-es2015.js
https://cdn.net/app/31-es2015.js
```

When deploying new version I need to change the version query string (as can be seen above) as otherwise when angular requests:

```
https://cdn.net/app/30-es2015.js
```
it loads cached version because the `max-age` is set to a year and its cached in the CDN anyways so it wouldn't get latest version.

This would be ok if I could control the query string of lazy loaded modules. Is that possible?

Thank you for any suggestions or help :-)

```
Angular CLI: 8.0.4
Node: 10.13.0
OS: win32 x64
Angular: 8.1.0-next.3
... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... language-service, platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic

Issues.Title: CLI lint builder ignores tslint severity setting
Issues.Body:
<!--üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ

Oh hi there! üòÑ

To expedite issue processing please search open and closed issues before submitting a new one.
Existing issues often contain information about workarounds, resolution, or progress updates.

üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ-->


# üêû Bug report

### Command (mark with an `x`)
<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are effected by this bug? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: -->
```
- [ ] new
- [ ] build
- [ ] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [x] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc
```

### Is this a regression?

<!-- Did this behavior use to work in the previous version? -->

Not sure. Possibly a regression caused by the new builders API.


### Description

TSLint provides control on the rules' severity. The severity could be `warn`/`error`. Currently the CLI always exits with code 1 if there are linting errors found in the project.

## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction
<!--
Simple steps to reproduce this bug.

Please include: commands run (including args), packages added, related code changes.

If reproduction steps are not enough for reproduction of your issue, please create a minimal GitHub repository with the reproduction of the issue. 
A good way to make a minimal reproduction is to create a new app via `ng new repro-app` and add the minimum possible code to show the problem. 
Share the link to the repo below along with step-by-step instructions to reproduce the problem, as well as expected and actual behavior.

Issues that don't have enough info and can't be reproduced will be closed.

You can read more about issue submission guidelines here: https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#-submitting-an-issue
-->

1. In a project introduce a linting error.
1. Run `ng lint`
1. `echo $?`
1. Update the rule severity to `error`
1. Run `ng lint` again
1. `echo $?`

In both cases the output will be 1.

## üåç Your Environment

^8.0.0

Issues.Title: web worker with deploy-url CDN cause SecurityError
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) ``` - [ ] new - [x] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ``` ### Is this a regression? no ### Description Angular 8 support build web worker command, but when the app deploys to CDN with ` --deploy-url`, the web worker ts will also loaded from the CDN URL. This will cause cross domain error ``` ERROR Error: Uncaught (in promise): SecurityError: Failed to construct 'Worker': ``` It makes that impossible to use web worker with `@angular/cli` in the production environment Angular CLI should support cross-domain web worker loader with options or by default * add plugin to `worker-plugin` like the code below https://github.com/GoogleChromeLabs/worker-plugin#plugins ```ts async () => { const codeString = await fetch(originWorkerUrl).then(res => res.text()); const localWorkerUrl = window.URL.createObjectURL(new Blob([codeString], { type: 'application/javascript' })); } ``` * or replace `worker-plugin` with `worker-loader` which support cross-origin-policy https://github.com/webpack-contrib/worker-loader#cross-origin-policy https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/277d4abd4b3172abbcd7b7c3bbe83d894887f9f7/packages/angular_devkit/build_angular/src/angular-cli-files/models/webpack-configs/worker.ts#L13 * or should give an option to deploy the web worker build out to the assets folder ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction https://angular.io/guide/web-worker with `ng build --prod --deploy-url` to any CDN url can easily reproduce this error ## üî• Exception or Error 

ERROR Error: Uncaught (in promise): SecurityError: Failed to construct 'Worker': Script at 'http://assets.daily.xxx.net/xxx.worker.js' cannot be accessed from origin 'http://daily.abc.xxx.net'.

Issues.Title: fix(ng-update): do not rely on node-glob for finding rule directories
Issues.Body:
We currently use `glob` in order to find rule directories automatically. This
has implications because it means that we depend on `glob` that is usually
brought in transitively by other project dependencies. This means that the
glob version is not guaranteed to be working due to previous `glob`
issues on windows.

Related to #16208

Issues.Title: Performance degradation when using an animated progress bar with multiple monitors
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

Use StackBlitz to reproduce your issue: https://stackblitz.com/fork/components-issue

Steps to reproduce:
1. Setup two monitors: 144hz, 60hz.
2. Open the progress bar example with the buffer mode: https://components-issue-4bf67t.stackblitz.io
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

What behavior were you expecting to see?

Using animations should not significantly affect system performance.


#### Actual Behavior

What behavior did you actually see?

There is a performance impact on the main monitor with massive stutters. It forces the main display at 60hz.

It was not reproduced by me because I don't have multiple monitors but was reported by users multiple times with the same monitor configurations.

The problem was fixed by switching the animation mode from 'buffer' to 'determinate'. It was confirmed by users.

I'm creating this issue to find more affected people.

Feedbacks from affected users:
```
there's an issue with 144hz/60hz dual monitors setups with the website. The fact that there's that pretty animation scrolling on the bottom forces the display to update at 60hz, which, through the power of the magnificent DWM that can't handle this in 2019, forces the main display at 60hz and with massive stutters. Switching to a different tab in the browser fixes this.
```
```
this is gonna sound weird, but when i had the tab with the site open just now on my secondary monitor and waiting for a trade to pop, it really killed the performance of my game client. like it was forcing a vsync ingame or something, very noticeably choppy. it could be just a one off thing i dont know, just bringing it up in case anyone else gets that and can confirm/deny. my primary monitor is 144hz, secondary is 60hz.
i could just need a pc restart. my pc acts weird sometimes when i wake it from sleep and just go about doing my normal stuff
```

#### Environment

- Angular: 8.0.0
- CDK/Material: 8.0.0
- Browser(s): Google Chrome
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows 10
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Performance degradation when using an animated progress bar with multiple monitors" (#16389)

Issues.Title: MatSelect- "Open Down Always"
Issues.Body:
#### Feature Description

The logic in the select to figure out whether to open up or down is great, but if we don't want this behavior there's no easy way to get around it.  If we just want the autocomplete to open downward all the time, even if it goes off the screen, or upwards, there should be a way to indicate this.

`@Input positioning: FLEXIBLE | UP | DOWN`

Same concept as `matAutocompletePosition` for Autocomplete

#### Use Case

Client does not want flexible positioning, UI requires the overlay to open "like a drawer" downward at all times
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "MatSelect- "Open Down Always"" (#16383)

Issues.Title: feat(drag-drop): add support for automatic scrolling
Issues.Body:
* Adds support for automatically scrolling either the list or the viewport when the user's cursor gets within a certain threshold of the edges (currently within 5% inside and outside).
* Handles changes to the scroll position of both the list and the viewport while the user is dragging. Previously our positioning would break down and we'd emit incorrect data.
* No longer blocks the mouse wheel scrolling while the user is dragging.
* Allows the consumer to opt out of the automatic scrolling.

Fixes #13588.
![list-demo](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4450522/60122076-bafb0100-9784-11e9-9f30-3d0d5b44038b.gif)
![viewport-demo](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4450522/60122077-bafb0100-9784-11e9-8b23-bf79c4cebb73.gif)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(drag-drop): add support for automatic scrolling" (#16382)

Issues.Title: Input chip: secondary placeholder
Issues.Body:
#### Feature Description

Add an optional _secondary placeholder_ for chips input component.

#### Use Case

In _Angular Material_ for _Angular.js_ chips input could have a _secondary placeholder_ for when one chip was already present in the input. IMHO this increases the user experience by letting him know that chips can be added.

![angular-material-chip-input-secondary-placeholder](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6987084/60116668-823c3700-9746-11e9-98d1-bcb1f089e344.gif)

Reference: https://material.angularjs.org/1.1.0/demo/chips
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Input chip: secondary placeholder" (#16380)

Issues.Title: mat-expansion-panel doesn't scroll to the header in safari IOS
Issues.Body:
mat-expansion-panel doesn't scroll to the header when the next and previous actions are performed from the mat-action-row in Safari IOS. It works perfectly fine in Chrome.

Is there a workaround to support safari browser. Thanks in advance

#### Reproduction
Here is the link to reproduce the issue https://angular-expansion-panel-safari-scroll-issue.stackblitz.io/

#### Steps to reproduce:
1. Open the link in safari browser
2. Click on next you'll see the panel scrolls to the middle of the next panel, this is not the case with chrome

#### Environment

- Angular: 8.0.0
- Browser(s): Safari - v12.1.1
- Operating System: macOS - v10.14.5
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "mat-expansion-panel doesn't scroll to the header in safari IOS" (#16378)

# CodePen and steps to reproduce the issue:
#### [CodePen Demo](https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-tooltip-material-syx76p?file=src%2Fapp%2Ftooltip%2Fbasictooltip.html) which demonstrates the issue: 


#### Detailed Reproduction Steps:

2. after page load go to page inspect try to find "staic tooltip message" button tooltip. Working fine
3. Unable to do automation due to this issue.
### What is the expected behavior?
even in data binding  page inspect should able to find tooltip message

### What is the current behavior?
page inspect unable to find tooltip message

### What is the use-case or motivation for changing an existing behavior?
in Devoops world Automation is very important. it will break to find tooltip messages when it is loading from ts file.

### Which versions of AngularJS, Material, OS, and browsers are affected?

- OS: windows
- Browsers: chrome 75.0.3770.100

Issues.Title: mat-tab-group ignores parent width when inside fxLayout row
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

[Stackblitz](https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-qube6g)

Steps to reproduce:
1. Add `mat-tab-group` inside div container having `fxFlexLayout="row"`
2. Add more `mat-tab` elements than the parent container width can display
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

The tab header should provide the usual left and right arrow indicating that there are more tabs than the current view shows (as it does if inside a fxLayout="column")

#### Actual Behavior

The tab-group grows in width and actually renders alls tabs even if there is no space. There are no arrows.

#### Environment

- Angular: ^8.0.0
- CDK/Material: ^8.0.1
- Browser(s): Chrome 75.0.3770.100
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): macOS
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "mat-tab-group ignores parent width when inside fxLayout row" (#16371)
